marketNews.title: Inflation and Trade Balance Surplus Exceed Expectations
marketNews.content:
BPS noted that Indonesia's inflation in June 2025 was 1.87% YoY (vs. May 2025: 1.6% YoY, June 2024: 2.51% YoY), higher than the consensus expectation of 1.83% YoY although in line with Bank Indonesia's target range of 1.5-3.5%.
Annually, inflation was driven by the group 'personal care and other services' which contributed 0.59 percentage point, with 0.48 percentage point coming from jewelry gold commodities. Meanwhile, the group 'food, beverages, and tobacco' contributed 0.58 percentage point to the annual inflation in June 2025.
Monthly, Indonesia recorded 0.19% MoM inflation in June 2025 (vs. May 2025: deflation of 0.37% MoM, June 2024: deflation of 0.08% MoM). Meanwhile, core inflation slowed to 2.37% YoY in June 2025 (vs. May 2025: 2.4% YoY inflation, June 2024: 1.9% YoY inflation), slightly lower than the consensus expectation which projected 2.44% YoY core inflation.
Besides inflation, BPS also noted that Indonesia's trade balance surplus reached 4.3 billion US dollars in May 2025 (vs. April 2025: 158.8 million US dollars, May 2024: 2.9 billion US dollars), exceeding the consensus expectation which projected a surplus of 2.4 billion US dollars. This result was driven by export growth of +9.68% YoY in May 2025, far exceeding the consensus expectation of +1% YoY. Meanwhile, imports in May 2025 grew by +4.14% YoY, also higher than the consensus expectation of -0.1% YoY.
Cumulatively during 5M25, Indonesia's trade balance recorded a surplus of 15.38 billion US dollars. The increase in exports of +6.98% YoY during 5M25 was mainly driven by an increase from the group 'animal and vegetable fats/oils' (CPO) by +33.1% YoY. Meanwhile, imports increased more moderately by +5.45% YoY, which was primarily suppressed by crude oil imports (-11.75% YoY).

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: The low inflation figures and supportive trade balance figures for the rupiah exchange rate potentially provide more room for Bank Indonesia to lower interest rates again. Bank Indonesia itself is expected to cut interest rates by another 50 bps to the 5% level by the end of 2025, based on the Bloomberg consensus.

marketNews.title: Other hot things you need to know...
marketNews.content:
1. The government officially issued a number of regulations related to goods imports as part of policy deregulation to strengthen the national economy. The Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs, Airlangga Hartarto, said on Monday (30/6) that there are policy changes regarding prohibitions and restrictions for 10 main commodities. Meanwhile, the Minister of Trade, Budi Santoso, stated that he has signed 9 regulations related to this, divided into several clusters according to their respective objectives, namely Ministerial Regulation of Trade numbers 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24 of 2025.
2. The Minister of Finance, Sri Mulyani, stated that the 2025 State Budget deficit is projected to reach 2.78% of GDP. This projection is higher compared to the 2025 State Budget target of 2.53% of GDP and has the potential to be the largest deficit in the last 2 decades (excluding the pandemic), although it remains below the 3% limit mandated by regulation. During 1H25 alone, the 2025 State Budget deficit reached 0.81% of GDP (vs. 1H24: 0.34% of GDP). This latest projection comes only a few days after Sri Mulyani last week said that the government is committed to fiscal discipline and estimates the 2025 State Budget deficit will reach 2.5% of GDP.
3. Bloomberg reported that BPI Danantara is seeking a multi-currency loan of up to 10 billion US dollars for general corporate purposes, which could become the largest credit facility in Southeast Asia. Bloomberg sources mentioned that Danantara has sent proposals to regional and international banks for a loan with a tenor of around 3-5 years. Danantara has not commented on this news from Bloomberg. In separate news, Kontan reported that Danantara is projected to receive funding of 10 billion US dollars from foreign banks in July 2025.
4. The Director General of Land Transportation of the Ministry of Transportation, Aan Suhanan, stated that they will raise two-wheeled online motorcycle taxi (ojol) fares by about +8-15% per kilometer, depending on zoning. Aan mentioned that this increase still requires approval from the application parties. The discourse on raising ojol fares is the government's response to driver complaints regarding disproportionate income relative to operational costs.
5. Bloomberg reported that China will extend anti-dumping duties on stainless steel product imports for the next 5 years, including from Indonesia. This policy, which has been in effect since July 2019, is intended to protect China's industry from oversupply and global trade uncertainty. The duty tariff for stainless steel products from Indonesia remains at 20.2%, the European Union and the UK at 43%, and for most South Korean companies reaches 103.1%.
6. S&P Global noted that Indonesia's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 46.9 in June 2025 (vs. May 2025: 47.4), marking a contraction in factory activity for the 3rd consecutive month. This result was pressured by new orders which fell for the 3rd straight month at the sharpest rate since August 2021. Meanwhile, S&P Global noted that China's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 50.4 in June 2025 (vs. May 2025: 48.3), exceeding the consensus expectation of 49. This increase was supported by output growing at the fastest pace since November 2024 along with rising new orders amid improving trade conditions and promotional activities.
7. BPS noted that foreign tourist (wisman) visits to Indonesia reached ~1.3 million people in May 2025 (+14% YoY, +12% MoM). This result brought the cumulative wisman visits to ~5.6 million people during 5M25 (+7.4% YoY), equivalent to 35-40% of the government's 2025 target in the range of 14-16 million people.

marketNews.title: Benefit Method Enhanced Dollar Cost Averaging
marketNews.content: "EDCA reduces the risk of bad timing, but does not guarantee profit." - JPH668

tickerNews.title: MAPI Targets Net Profit Growth in Low-Single Digit for 2025
tickerNews.content: Mitra Adiperkasa Deputy President Director, Virendra Prakash Sharma, stated that the company targets net profit growth of low-single digit during 2025 (vs. 2025F consensus estimate: +13% YoY, 2024 realization: -6.7% YoY), with a revenue target in the high-single digit range (vs. 2025F consensus estimate: +8.6% YoY, 2024 realization: +14% YoY). This target takes into account Indonesia's weaker macroeconomic conditions compared to the previous year. MAPI itself plans to budget capital expenditure worth 2 trillion rupiah during 2025 for expansion, including for the expansion of 40 new Starbucks outlets through MAP Boga Adiperkasa (MAPB). Since early 2025, MAPB has closed 16 Starbucks outlets and opened 11 new ones.

tickerNews.title: MDKA Recorded Net Loss of 3.7 Million Dollars in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: Merdeka Copper Gold recorded a net loss of 3.7 million US dollars in 1Q25 (vs. 4Q24: net profit of 11.3 million US dollars, 1Q24: loss of 15.2 million US dollars), compared to the 2025F consensus estimate which projected a net profit of 3.8 million US dollars. Revenue stood at 502 million US dollars (-12% QoQ, -7% YoY) and EBITDA was 88.6 million US dollars (-18% QoQ, +57% YoY).

tickerNews.title: MBMA Recorded Net Loss of 3.5 Million Dollars in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: Merdeka Battery Materials recorded a net loss of 3.5 million US dollars (vs. 4Q24: net profit of 4.3 million US dollars, 1Q24: profit of 3.7 million US dollars), compared to the 2025F consensus estimate which expected a net profit of 41.8 million US dollars. Revenue stood at 366 million US dollars (-21% QoQ, -18% YoY) and EBITDA was 31.1 million US dollars (-36% QoQ, +17% YoY).

tickerNews.title: MEDC Subsidiary Signs Credit Facility Up to 500 Million USD
tickerNews.content: Medco Energi Internasional through its subsidiaries, Medco E&P Grissik Ltd. and Far East Energy Trading Pte. Ltd., signed a credit facility of up to 500 million US dollars from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited, ING Bank N.V., MUFG Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank with a tenor of up to September 30, 2028. This facility is intended as part of the company's medium-term funding strategy.

tickerNews.title: YUPI to Distribute Total Dividend of 187.3 Rupiah per Share
tickerNews.content: Yupi Indo Jelly Gum will distribute a dividend for the 2024 fiscal year amounting to 58.9 rupiah per share. Additionally, YUPI will also distribute 91% of retained earnings as an additional final dividend equivalent to 128.4 rupiah per share. This makes the total dividend to be distributed by YUPI reach 187.3 rupiah per share, indicating a dividend yield of 8.6% as of Tuesday (1/7). The cum-date in the regular and negotiation market is July 4, 2025, while payment is on July 10, 2025.

tickerNews.title: GJTL to Distribute 2024 Fiscal Year Dividend of 50 Rupiah per Share
tickerNews.content: Gajah Tunggal will distribute a dividend for the 2024 fiscal year valued at 174.2 billion rupiah or 50 rupiah per share. This amount is equivalent to a 15% dividend payout ratio (vs. 2023: 15%) and indicates a dividend yield of 4.5% as of Tuesday (1/7). The cum-date in the regular and negotiation market is July 4, 2025, while payment is on July 30, 2025.
